question: A simple pendulum has a period of 2 seconds on Earth. If the pendulum is taken to a planet with twice the acceleration due to gravity of Earth, what will be the new period of the pendulum?
solution: The period of a simple pendulum is given by the formula T = 2π√(L/g), where L is the length of the pendulum and g is the acceleration due to gravity. If the acceleration due to gravity doubles, then the period will be multiplied by a factor of √(1/2), which is equal to 1/√2. Therefore, the new period will be T_new = T_old / √2 = 2 seconds / √2 = √2 seconds.
